sect1.title: Locating the Dashboard
sect1.para: If you are unsure of the location of the &dashboard;, run the following command:
The command returns the URL where the &dashboard; is located: (https://host:port/)

sect1.title: Accessing the &dashboard;
sect1.para: If you are unable to access the &dashboard;, run through the following commands.

step.para: Ensure the &dashboard; module is listed in the enabled_modules section. Example snipped output from the ceph mgr module ls command:
If it is not listed, activate the module with the following command:
Check the &dashboard;mgr log file for any errors:
Ensure the SSL/TSL support is configured properly:
Verify the self-signed certificate exists. If not, run:
See for more information on self-signed certificates or for information on self-signed certificates by CA.

sect1.title: Trouble Logging into the &dashboard;
sect1.para: If you are unable to log into the &dashboard; and you receive the following error, run through the procedural checks below:

step.para: Check that your user credentials are correct. If you are seeing the notification message above when trying to log into the &dashboard;, it is likely you are using the wrong credentials. Double check your username and password, and ensure the caps lock key is not enabled by accident.
If your user credentials are correct, but you are experiencing the same error, check that the user account exists:
This command returns your user data. If the user does not exist, it will print:
step.screen: Error ENOENT: User USERNAME does not exist
step.para: In this case, you will need to create the user. See for more information on user accounts.
Check if the user is enabled:
Check if enabled is set to true for your user. If not the user is not enabled, run:

sect1.title: A &dashboard; Feature is Not Working
sect1.para: When an error occurs on the backend, you will usually receive an error notification on the frontend. Run through the following scenarios to debug.

step.para: Check the &dashboard;/mgr logfile(s) for any errors. These can be identified by searching for keywords, such as 500 Internal Server Error, followed by traceback. The end of a traceback contains more details about what exact error occurred.
Check your web browser's Javascript Console for any errors.

sect2.title: Debug &dashboard; Flag
sect2.para: With this flag enabled, traceback of errors are included in backend responses.
To enable this flag via the &dashboard;, navigate from Cluster to Manager modules. Select Dashboard module and click the edit button. Click the debug checkbox and update.
To enable via the CLI, run the following command:

sect2.title: Setting Logging Level of &dashboard; Module
sect2.para: Setting the logging level to debug makes the log more verbose and helpful for debugging.

step.para: Increase the logging level of manager daemons:
Adjust the logging level of the &dashboard; module via the &dashboard; or CLI:

listitem.para: Navigate from Cluster to Manager modules. Select Dashboard module and click the edit button. Modify the log_level configuration.
To adjust via the CLI, run the following command:
